subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: April Abercrombie

Content-Type: text/plain;

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Yeah-I know about the file size comparison. Obviously if the file size beca=
me smaller, we know for sure there has been loss, except if the file had be=
en saved to a lossless compression type, such as from RAW to TIFF in photo =
files.

I just don't fully trust the bit comparison because I don't trust t=
hat the bytes haven't been resampled using interpolation, such as we discus=
sed earlier. But that is largely because I have no clue at that level of th=
ings what is actually going on.

All I know about this I know from Graphic =
Design experience and working with photo files, so I only have that knowled=
ge to use to compare. I no nothing about actual programming language, Unix,=
 or stuff like that.

April

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Rj 
  =
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 4:13 PM
  Subject=
: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON





        They are no=
t necessarily the same bytes, but I was proposing a quick check just to see=
 if the files were in the same ballpark.  Look at it the other way: if the =
number of bytes were DIFFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD changed, and =
you could stop testing.  But if the number of bytes are the same, it tends =
to indicate the files are likely the same, but you still need a low level f=
ile comparison to be sure.

        My method is to compare the files using=
 the CMP command in unix.  There are many programs to compare files, but yo=
u have to be careful not to use one that does a line-by-line compare (or a =
comparison meant for text files), since text files can be different at a lo=
w level, but look essential the same in an editor (because of the way space=
s and tabs and new lines work between editors and platforms).

        But =
anyway, the way to compare is with a program that can compare binary files,=
 not text files.


        --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@ab=
ercrombieghostresearch.com> wrote:


          From: April Abercrombie <apr=
il@...>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uplo=
ading rules-ATTENTION JON
          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          D=
ate: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:42 PM



          So if the number of bytes m=
atch then they are the same bytes? See where my confusion comes in?

      =
    How does one do a bit-level comparison? Is there a program that does th=
at, or is there some way of comparison by looking at the file's properties?=


            ----- Original Message ----- 
            From: Rj 
         =
   To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
            Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 3:3=
5 PM
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
=


                  A file's content, it's integrity, is simply the bytes (=
and their bits) in the file.  If the file's content integrity is changed, t=
hat is, by definition, changing the bytes.  If the bytes in there are not c=
hanged, then that integrity has not changed.

                  It is possi=
ble to mess with other things about a file (like its name, its suffix, or i=
ts ownership) but this does not effect the contents, and so would not affec=
t that integrity, or the sound of the file (assuming you could read it at a=
ll after changing the ownership, or the suffix, etc).

                  Wh=
en you do your tests, if you cannot do a bit level comparison, I would reco=
mmend at least checking the file sizes.  If they are identical, there is a =
very high probability that the content has not changed.




               =
   --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch.=
 com> wrote:


                    From: April Abercrombie <april@abercromb=
iegh ostresearch. com>
                    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uplo=
ading rules-ATTENTION JON
                    To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
=
                    Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:28 PM



                =
    Admittedly I do not know much about bit-level comparisons, what they ca=
n or can't show so I will have to leave that to you. I have doubts because =
I worry once a file's integrity has been messed with, I wonder that even th=
ough the bits match, maybe that doesn't mean they are the same quality as t=
he original. I really don't know though what is possible or impossible when=
 it comes to this area.

                    "It is probably possible to se=
t up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My =
tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we=
 can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment wou=
ld be very unusual."

                    The problem I have is that not ju=
st from Jon, but I have heard it from other people, and a professional and =
they all said that loss is possible. From all that, my conclusion was that =
maybe in some cases loss was possible.

                    However, your a=
rguments do put doubt back into my mind, which pisses me off, because I had=
 originally argued feverishly for no loss, then I heard different from diff=
erent sources and decided to do what I thought was the right thing by conta=
cting a third party professional. So after all that, I decided I was licked=
 and had to eat crow.

                    Now I am back at square one, fro=
m the other side LOL!!! Computer people have been wrong in the past.


    =
                "It is probably possible to set up an email compression sch=
eme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does not.=
  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I=
 see, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual."

       =
             I have not tested it from my computer, as I haven't had any pr=
oblems with loss. I would really like to have Jon work with us on this, bec=
ause he was the original person who told me I was wrong.

                 =
   But I will test it from my side. I will send a wav file to one of my oth=
er addresses. Then I will download and compare. If I think I hear a differe=
nce, then maybe I can have you do a bit-level comparison on the files.

   =
                 Either way, I am going to get to the bottom of this.



  =
                    ----- Original Message ----- 
                      Fro=
m: Rj 
                      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                =
      Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:59 PM
                      Subject: Re:=
 [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON


                           =
 Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit-level comparison.  An audio file=
 is just a file of bytes, that is later interpreted by an audio player.  Tw=
o files with the exact same contents, whether they are audio or image or a =
dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable from each other.  That is, if I c=
opied the contents of one to a new file, and the contents of the other to a=
 new file, and asked you which file each came from, there would be no way t=
o tell.  Even the audio player could not tell.  The data is identical, and =
so the sound (or the picture, etc) would be identical.

                   =
         Yes I did listen to the results, but that is not the best test (th=
ey sounded identical, but that is a subjective opinion).  The real test is =
compring the contents.  Identical contents means indentical data, means ide=
ntical audio.

                            It is probably possible to set u=
p an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tes=
ts show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we ca=
n do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment would =
be very unusual.


                            --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April A=
bercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                =
              From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com=
>
                              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules=
-ATTENTION JON
                              To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
 =
                             Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 1:50 PM



       =
                       I have not personally experienced the loss myself. J=
on from this list is the one who originally told me about it. I have also h=
eard of it happening to a few other people. After my conversation with Jon,=
 I talked to a computer professional, and he told me that you can experienc=
e loss in attached files.

                              I don't know if yo=
u would be able to tell loss of quality in an audio file with a bit-level c=
omparison. Just because the data has been replaced, doesn't have to mean it=
 is perfect.

                              Did you listen to the before an=
d after results?

                              Jon-Please relay your exper=
ience with the loss of quality on emailed files.


                        =
        ----- Original Message ----- 
                                From:=
 Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
        =
                        Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
                =
                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


             =
                   I can't vouch for your computer or servers, but I just d=
id some tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once a=
llowing compression, and once turning it off.   I was able to verify that o=
ne was compressed and one was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived =
at Yahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of =
the original, and the ones sent around email.  They were all identical, whi=
ch indicates lossless compression.

                                If you =
have a file you'd like me to test for you, let me know.  But I wouldn't tak=
e someone's word for how your server's work, without testing them yourself.=




                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie =
<april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                           =
     From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
       =
                         Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
      =
                          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                    =
            Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM



                       =
         For executables, you may be right. However, for wav files, the com=
pression during email is not loss less. 

                                I=
 used to think as you do, in that the emailed attachment of a wav file woul=
d not loose anything. After a lengthy discourse with another member here, I=
 learned that I was wrong. The reason why I did not realize it in the first=
 place is that when I would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it=
 in very small segments, to keep file size down. This was just for ease of =
transfer. But because of this, I had not experienced any noticeable loss.

=
                                Now it may be in some cases, depending on t=
he servers or what have you that the file goes through, that the loss may b=
e less or more. But once the attachment is downloaded, the quality has been=
 found to be less then the original wav.

                                A=
gain though you can only really tell when the wav file is large.

         =
                       ----- Original Message ----- 
                      =
          From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups=
 .com 
                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
 =
                               Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
=


                                The kind of compression that occurs durin=
g an email attachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly without =
losing information.  For example, if I had a program in some .exe files, an=
d I sent it over email, it could compress it.  But if it lost even one bit,=
 the resulting exe file would not execute again after it was uncompressed o=
n the other side.

                                This kind of compression=
 does things like looking for common patterns in the file, and replacing th=
em with a token.  A rough example would be if it found "Howdy Neighbor" in =
a file 20 times, it could replace all the occurances with say $HN1.  And al=
so write a little dictionary in there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Nei=
ghbor".

                                When the file gets to its destinat=
ion it can be uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are replaced with "H=
owdy Neighbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 characters each, it on=
ly needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no data.

                     =
           Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not lossless.  Depending on=
 the level of compression, some level of data is lost, and so cannot be rec=
overed or reconstructed later.

                                Rick



   =
                             --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@=
abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                Fr=
om: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
              =
                  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
             =
                   To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                           =
     Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM



                              =
  Another thing:

                                I recently found this out=
. When you email a file, if it is not saved as a compressed format, the ema=
il filtering process will actually compress the file automatically.

      =
                          So even if you have attached a wav. file, it will=
 loose resolution over the email process. It will not sound exactly the sam=
e as the original wav. file. How much it differs depends on the size of the=
 file you are attaching. If it is a very large file, it will sound much dif=
ferent.

                                The only exception to this is if t=
he wav. file is small enough that the filtering process will ignore it. It =
has to be pretty small though, like under 1 MB (I am not exactly sure of th=
e threshold).

                                The best way to share files =
over the internet if you want them as close to the original as possible is =
to upload them directly to a website.

                                ----=
- Original Message ----- 
                                From: Rj 
       =
                         To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                    =
            Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                           =
     Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules



                       =
         Pixelization doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine t=
aking a picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixel=
ization to the picture.  Soon, you would not be able to tell there were flo=
wers there at all.  You would see a lot of colored blocks.

               =
                 Or in the other direction, imagine you are looking at a co=
mpetely randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a complete screen of truel=
y random static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a while, you would again star=
t to see colored blocks.

                                What's happening =
is that it is processing an area of the image, taking (for instance) the av=
erage value of that entire area, and replacing all the blocks in that area =
with the average.  In video processing, this would result in a field of mul=
ti-colored flowers being replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish bl=
ock, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe replac=
e all the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.  If you did =
not know beforehand what the original picture was, you couldn't tell whethe=
r your pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with=
 clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

                                It w=
orks the same with the sound files.  Taking something as complex as speech,=
 and replacing frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the farthe=
r you go, until you head strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the same =
to random static will eventually produce the same thing.  And random fluctu=
ating square waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you could hav=
e fun sharing with each other what you thing they 'sound like'.





      =
                          --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yah=
oo.com> wrote:


                                From: Misty Dawn <bulletba=
bea@ yahoo.com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File=
 uploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .c=
om
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:29 AM


  =
                              I always save the whole file in wav format th=
en do my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. 

           =
                     As far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise whos =
to say that isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a form of =
white noise. I seem to remember some experiments done with blank tapes/film=
, no recording done yet there were voices/images there. I find it all inter=
esting.

                                Just a thought. Ok off to work now=
!
                                Misty

                                --=
- On Sun, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


                      =
          From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                                Su=
bject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                T=
o: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, M=
ay 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


                                Be a bit careful of=
 formats like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the sounds though=
.   While some formats (like wav) can store the audio very close to the way=
 it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in so doing lose =
some of the sonic details.  This may not be a big deal in music, where the =
audio is fairly clear to begin with.  But with sound sources with a lot of =
noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any real sounds, but pixelize =
non-sounds (like white noise) and make them start to sound like speech.

  =
                              So mp3 might be good for sharing the data, on=
ce you've already formed an opinion based on an analysis of the wav file.  =
But mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to many false po=
sitives and misinterpretations.

                                --- On Sun=
, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                   =
             From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                    =
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules

ate: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM

n is right thats how you save it. For most softwares its under save as or e=
xport as. If you still have trouble use one of the links I posted to help y=
a out.

                                Misty

            =
    <TD vAlign=3Dtop>A file's content, it's integrity, is simply the 
     =
             bytes (and their bits) in the file.  If the file's 
     =
             content integrity is changed, that is, by definition, changing=
 
                  the bytes.  If the bytes in there are not changed,=
 then 
                  that integrity has not changed.<BR><BR>It is possi=
ble to mess 
                  with other things about a file (like its nam=
e, its suffix, or 
                  its ownership) but this does not effec=
t the contents, and so 
                  would not affect that integrity, =
or the sound of the file 
                  (assuming you could read it at =
all after changing the 
                  ownership, or the suffix, etc).<B=
R><BR>When you do your tests, 
                  if you cannot do a bit lev=
el comparison, I would recommend at 
                  least checking the f=
ile sizes.  If they are identical, 
                  there is a very =
high probability that the content has not 
                  changed.<BR><B=
R><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, April 
                  Abercrombie =
<I><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                  com></I></B> =
wrote:<BR>

                    style=3D"BORD=

bits match, maybe 
                    that doesn't mean they are the same =
quality as the original. 
                    I really don't know though wh=

                    when it comes to this are=

                          <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Yes you can tel=
l loss of quality by a 
                            bit-level comparison.&n=
bsp; An audio file is just a 
                            file of bytes, th=
at is later interpreted by an audio 
                            player.&nb=
sp; Two files with the exact same 
                            contents, wh=
ether they are audio or image or a 
                            dababase or=
 an exe, are indistinguishable from each 
                            other=
.  That is, if I copied the contents of 
                            o=
ne to a new file, and the contents of the other to 
                       =
     a new file, and asked you which file each came from, 
                =
            there would be no way to tell.  Even the audio 
          =
                  player could not tell.  The data is identical, 
    =
                        and so the sound (or the picture, etc) would be 
  =
                          identical.<BR><BR>Yes I did listen to the results=
, 
                            but that is not the best test (they sounded =

                            identical, but that is a subjective opinion).&=
nbsp; 
                            The real test is compring the contents.&=
nbsp; 
                            Identical contents means indentical data=
, means 
                            identical audio.<BR><BR>It is probably=
 possible to 
                            set up an email compression schem=
e that does do 
                            lossy audio compression.  =
My tests show my 
                            setup does not.  If you'=
d like me to help test 
                            your setup, we can do t=
hat too. From what I see, 
                            lossy compression fr=
om an attachment would be very 
                            unusual.<BR><BR=
><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, April

             =
                   <TD vAlign=3Dtop>I can't vouch for your computer 
      =
                          or servers, but I just did some tests, and sent 
=
                                a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back=
, 
                                once allowing compression, and once turn=
ing it 
                                off.   I was able to veri=
fy that one 
                                was compressed and one was not=
, by checking the 
                                sizes when they arrived =
at Yahoo. Once they came 
                                back to MSN, I th=
en did a bit-level comparison 
                                of the origi=
nal, and the ones sent around 
                                email. =
 They were all identical, which 
                                indicates =
lossless compression.<BR><BR>If you 
                                have a=
 file you'd like me to test for you, let 
                                m=
e know.  But I wouldn't take someone's 
                              =
  word for how your server's work, without testing 
                       =

                                <DIV

FONT-FAMILY: arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-WEIGHT: normal; font-size-adjust:=
 none"><B>Subject:</B>

     =

     <P>
                                <TABLE border=3D0 cellSpacing=3D0 =
cellPadding=3D0>
                                <TBODY>
                  =
              <TR>
                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>The kin=
d of compression that 
                                occurs during an ema=
il attachment is "lossless": 
                                it compress t=
he file cleverly without losing 
                                informatio=
n.  For example, if I had a 
                                program i=
n some .exe files, and I sent it over 
                                emai=
l, it could compress it.  But if it 
                                l=
ost even one bit, the resulting exe file would 
                           =
     not execute again after it was uncompressed on 
                      =
          the other side.<BR><BR>This kind of compression 
                =
                does things like looking for common patterns in 
          =
                      the file, and replacing them with a token.  
   =
                             A rough example would be if it found "Howdy 
 =
                               Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could repla=
ce 
                                all the occurances with say $HN1. =
 And also 
                                write a little dictionary in the=
re someplace 
                                that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neigh=
bor".<BR><BR>When the 
                                file gets to its des=
tination it can be 
                                uncompressed, and all o=
ccurences of $HN1 are 
                                replaced with "Howdy=
 Neighbor".  So it was 
                                compressed (in=
stead of 14 characters each, it 
                                only neede=
d 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no 
                                dat=
a.<BR><BR>Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
                               =
 are not lossless.  Depending on the level 
                          =
      of compression, some level of data is lost, and 
                    =
            so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                      =
          later.<BR><BR>Rick<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
               =
                 5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                              =
  <I><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                                =
com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
                                <BLOCKQUOTE 
   =
                             style=3D"BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px solid=
"><BR>From: 
                                April Abercrombie <april@ab=
ercrombiegh 
                                ostresearch. com><BR>Subjec=
t: Re: [EVP-ITC] 
                                File uploading rules<BR>T=
o: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups 
                                .com<BR>Date: Sunda=
y, May 10, 2009, 10:26 
                                AM<BR><BR>
        =
                        <DIV id=3Dyiv819860743>
                           =
     <DIV id=3Dygrp-text>
                                <P></P>
         =
                       <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">Another 
   =
                             thing:</FONT></DIV>
                          =
      <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
                                face=3D"Myriad P=
ro"></FONT> </DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2=
 face=3D"Myriad Pro">I recently 
                                found this=
 out. When you email a file, if it is 
                                not =
saved as a compressed format, the email 
                                fi=
ltering process will actually compress the 
                               =
 file automatically.</FONT></DIV>
                                <DIV><FON=
T size=3D2 
                                face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT>&nbs=
p;</DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad=
 Pro">So even if 
                                you have attached a wav. =
file, it will loose 
                                resolution over the em=
ail process. It will not 
                                sound exactly the=
 same as the original wav. 
                                file. How much =
it differs depends on the size of 
                                the file=
 you are attaching. If it is a 
                                very l=
arge file, it will sound much 
                                different.</=
FONT></DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
          =
                      face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
             =
                   <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">The only 
      =
                          exception to this is if the wav. file is small 
 =
                               enough that the filtering process will ignor=
e 
                                it. It has to be pretty small though, li=

D vAlign=3Dtop><BR>Pixelization doesn't clean-up 
                         =
       the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a 
                  =
              picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to 
            =
                    add levels or pixelization to the picture.  
     =
                           Soon, you would not be able to tell there were 
=
                                flowers there at all.  You would see a=
 lot 
                                of colored blocks.<BR><BR>Or in the o=
ther 
                                direction, imagine you are looking at=
 a 
                                competely randomize bunch of pixes on y=
our 
                                screen: a complete screen of truely ra=
ndom 
                                static snow.  Pixelizing this, a=
fter a 
                                while, you would again start to see=
 colored 
                                blocks.<BR><BR>What's happening i=
s that it is 
                                processing an area of the ima=
ge, taking (for 
                                instance) the average valu=
e of that entire area, 
                                and replacing all t=
he blocks in that area with 
                                the average.&n=
bsp; In video processing, this 
                                would resul=
t in a field of multi-colored flowers 
                                bein=
g replaced by, for instance, a big 
                                greyish=
-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
                                flow=
ers.  In the noise example, it maybe 
                                =
replace all the random pixels with another big 
                           =
     greyish-bluish block.  If you did not know 
                     =
           beforehand what the original picture was, you 
                 =
               couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was 
            =
                    really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with 
     =
                           clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.<BR><BR>It 
=
                                works the same with the sound files.  =

                                Taking something as complex as speech, and=
 
                                replacing frequencies with their averages=
, loses 
                                the speech the farther you go, unt=
il you head 
                                strange fluctuating square wav=
es.  Doing 
                                the same to random static =
will eventually 
                                produce the same thing.&nb=
sp; And random 
                                fluctuating square waves ca=
n sound a bit like 
                                speech - or at least, y=
ou could have fun sharing 
                                with each other =
what you thing they 'sound 
                                like'.<BR><BR><=
